title: Death Star Laser Turret
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Designed for use with X Wing miniatures game.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:

Originally printed in three stages. First print was just the two main turret parts. The second print was just the two gun gears and the third print was the gun barrells and muzzles. I only used a raft for the third print as the surface area of the gun barrels and muzzles on the bed is fairly small.
I printed in PLA and set a layer thickness of 0.1mm. I increased the top and bottom layer to 0.8mm and decreased the nozzle temperature to 200C. These were primarily to prevent cushioning on the top surface. I didn't use any supports for the hole in the base of the top part of the turret. It was a little messy, but cleaned up okay and didn't impact on the movement of the parts.

The project objective was to give young children (ages where 10-12) a chance to actually design there own 3d modules.. i know it sounds dull but it was awesome..
I took a small simple open source stl (maker faire robot)
15 minutes explained what a 3d printer ,designed in front of them some random thing to add to the module (for example)
told them that they can do what ever they want
put them in a room with computers for an hour and half. truthfully I did't expect it to work so well got a freakishly fast learning curve if you just let them at it .. then I printed there new improved modules for them.. they went crazy...

it's simple (very) but its such a dalm awesome class.. .

The basic tips the kids need to know.

after explaining how a 3d printer works.
1) tell them that the printer can not print on air,
everything should be connected and not fall under 60 degrees when there is nothing under..

2) everything has to have some width to be printed

both are easily explained ..
I found that letting them draw there design on a paper before , after which they come up to you and get an OK before there allowed to begin moduling helps a lot

Interduction

Introduce 3d printers- can be done in many ways.

Introduce tinkercad.
upload the maker faire model.
ask them for ideas of what to add.
Do NOT give concrete ideas only concepts so to let there imagination run wild.
Take one of there ideas and model it in front of them slowly while asking them how they think you should do it..

design step

pair them up.
ask them to draw on a peace of paper there design.
all designs must be approved before they take the next step.
keep in mind the physical constraints of 3d modeling.
Keep there designs simple.

Modeling step

Open each pair a tinkercad project with the maker faire robot.
Let them at it for two hours.
Do NOT model anything for them.
Do Not solve all there problems let them break there head on it for a while before guiding.
It will help them learn faster and better.
Guide as much as you can
Have fun.

Print step

go over models fix whats needed and print
spool adapter 52mm.

I needed a work light very quickly to work overnight. Also i was going to be inside a giant sign with no lights. I hadn't went out and bought myself one yet so I made it. I had all the parts so why not. I designed it and was ready to use in 4 1/2 hours, so it didn't fit my big head properly and the tabs for the elastic band broke off the one in the pictures. I didn't have time to reprint so I drilled holes in the sides for the elastic. It wasn't the prettiest thing but it worked perfect.

I beefed up the tabs for the elastic band in the .stl file so they shouldn't snap off.

The led is a HanleyLED P-2027
The switch was salvaged from a broken toy
standard 9V battery Connector
Me inside a huge sign located in a north suburb of Chicago

title: Adjustable Z probe for Bed Auto Leveling (Prusa i3)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Here a simply update for add Auto Bed-Leveling system to your i3 Prusa Rework style printer (like mine Poang 3D).

The Probe is Adjustable and you can mount the stand part directly on the bracket of the extruder.

You need also a Hall magnetic sensor like this one:
http://www.dx.com/p/new-hall-sensor-module-for-arduino-black-152092#.V0yNLjWLSWg

I've used in addiction 2x mini-magnets 5x5x5 mm and some 3 mm screws and bolts.
Full information here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Adjustable-Z-Probe-for-Bed-Auto-Leveling-i3-Prusa-/

This upgrade concerns my 3D Printer Poang 3D, here you can find the entire project: http://www.instructables.com/id/From-an-Ikea-Footstool-to-Poang-3D-Printer/

Enjoy it!

Notes:

All PrintrBot prints were done with 3 shells and varying speeds from 30 mm/sec to 100 mm/sec. I would not recommend going over 50 mm/sec, as some extrusion problems occurred. I used a heated bed at a temperature between 60 & 70 degrees Celsius. Extruder temperature was at 205 degrees Celsius.
All prints were printed with a raft and support. Support should be used for the underside and the ears. The nose prints well without support. Prints were cleaned off using a sharp blade and a blunt chisel.

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15 - 0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Support obligatoire pour la pièce SupportChaineDroit (pièce rouge). Facultatif pour les autres pièces.

Mandatory support for part SupportChaineDroit (red part). Optional for other parts.

Instructions de montage / Setup instruction

Français

Le passage de chaine gauche de l'imprimante peut être positionné sur le côté de cette dernière ou sur l'avant.
2 goulottes gauches sont fournies: une courte et une longue (horizontalement). Par défaut c'est la courte qui est utilisée.

Le passage de chaîne situé sur le côté de l'imprimante devrait être constitué par les pièces suivantes:
SupportChaineGaucheVarianteArriere + GoulotteGaucheCourte

Le passage de chaîne situé sur l'avant de l'imprimante devrait être constitué par les pièces suivantes:
SupportChaineGaucheVarianteLaterale + GoulotteGaucheLongue

Le support de chaine de la tête d'impression (SupportChaineTete) est à visser sur la pièce de maintient de l'extrudeur à l'aide des vis existantes.

Le maillon de début de chaine ouvert (Bitmap: Début chaîne ouvert / STL: Debut2ChaineFinal.stl) se fixe verticalement sur le support de chaine droit.

Les goulottes sont à clipser sur les tiges verticales. Attention, il peut être nécessaire d'ébarber l'intérieur de la fixation, cette dernière risquant de se rompre.

English

Left side cable chain can be located on the side of the printer or on the front.

For side chain cable the following parts should be used:
SupportChaineGaucheVarianteArriere + GoulotteGaucheCourte
For front chain cable the following parts should be used:
SupportChaineGaucheVarianteLaterale + GoulotteGaucheLongue

Chain support for printing head (SupportChaineTete) has to be screwed on extruder maintaining part using existing screws.
Start chain opened hinge has to be attached vertically on right chain holder (SupportChaineDroit).
Troughs are to be connected on vertical rods. Be carrefull while doing so: trough connector are fragile and might break. You may need to increase hole diameter a bit using a cutter for instance.

Modification des câbles / Cables modification

Français

Tous les câbles doivent être rallongés sauf ceux du moteur X et, suivant la config de votre imprimante, le câble du palpeur inductif.

English

All wires have to be lengthened except X motor ones and, depending on your printer's configuration, inductive sensor ones.

Maj 14/06/2016 - Update 06/14/2016

Une erreur s'est glissée dans le fichier .step du support de chaîne de la tête d'impression (SupportChaineTeteFinal.step). Il faut inverser la symétrie sur l'axe Y.

There is a mistake with the file SupportChaineTeteFinal.step. It must be mirrored on Y axis.

description.text:
Couldn't find a decent 3D model of Reuleaux triangle (constant radius) available online, or others were modeled incorrectly. Decided to have a go myself. I believe this is a good challenge for modelers.
I will use this in a 2 part silicone mold to make plaster copies as inspired by http://fab.cba.mit.edu/classes/863.11/people/paulina.mustafa/02.html &
http://vloggest.com/watch/adam-savage-mini-science-fair-project-1070148843/
both of which I believe show incorrectly modeled triangles, which you can tell because the vertices should be indistinguishable however on those there is a clear bottom/top.

Printer:

Hacked Davinci 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Fine/Standard

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

I will print in ABS and vapor polish to make smooth for casting later

Solidworks

Modeled in Solidworks by intersection of circular pattern of a revolve, then circular pattern of that intersection about another axis, and finally combining the common area of these 3 solid bodies.

sketch equilateral triangle with arcs of radius equal to that of triangle side length, revolve two arcs and triangle area around opposite triangle side to create disc insert reference axis from intersection of two planes and circular pattern the BODY around this axis 3-fold intersect these bodies and remove the outer areas create 3d sketch and create two more reference planes then reference axis going that goes to another tetrahedron vertex circular pattern around this axis, same as before I ran into a problem when trying to use intersect (weird anomaly in model) so I dropped down the list of 3 solid bodies in feature tree and chose to combine them, using the common area. After this I sectioned into two printable parts and uploaded whole, top, and bottom STL's to make it printable.

This is a replica of a dragon egg based on the Game of Thrones. It has a slightly different shape than a bird's egg with both ends a bit more more symmetric. Also, it has scales manually put together one by one.

This was made using Thinkercad and took me around 6 hours to complete. Then, to make it more real, I used Meshmixer and added some imperfections to simulate exposure of thousands of years to the elements.

Project Name

Dragon Egg from Game of Thrones

Overview & Background

In the HBO Game of Thrones series, Daenerys Targaryen receives three petrified dragon eggs from Illyrio as a weeding gift. After looking online, I found the eggs for sale in the HBO store; unfortunately they cost $99. I decided to design them from scratch for anyone to print

Objectives

To design a dragon egg that resembles as much as possible to a "real" dragon egg. You would learn optimizing parameters for properly slicing a basic 3D object.

Audiences

Anyone interested in fantasy. It's actually a nice activity for art class as there is opportunity to improve the appearance by painting the egg afterwards.

Subjects

Reading (as it's based on the Game of Thrones book)
Arts
Geometry

Skills Learned (Standards)

Slicing 3d files
Using 3d printer
Cleaning 3d printed model

Lesson/Activity
  1. Download STL file
  2. Open a 3D Slicer program
  3. Ensure the object is centered
  4. Open the Slicer options and choose the best numbers for the following parameters assuming we want a hollow egg with no infill:
    Infill Density: ??
    Adhesion Type: Brim
    Support Type: Touching bed
    Shell Thickness: ??
    Overhang angle: ?? degrees

The egg can be printed with very little support as the bottom is a bit flat. I used transparent PLA and no Infill, which made the egg very light, but still resistant.

Duration

1/2 hour preparing and slicing
about 4 hour printing

Preparation

This needs printing filament, preferably White PLA
Having read or watch Game of Thrones
Some acrylic paint (red, black and green)

References

There are many different types of dragons. Please research what type of dragon do these eggs belong to based on shape and colors

Rubric & Assessment

By the end of the exercise students would understand how to use infill, how overhang angles affect the end result, and a bit about fantasy.

Handouts & Assets

description.header: Project: Push-down button with a ballpoint pen spring
description.text:
Project Name

This is a three piece push button combined with a ball-point pen spring. It can be pushed down and returns to initial position when released thanks to spring. After print, individually designed parts can easily be joined. Students can dissassemble it into orjinal parts whenever they want and reassemble it at once again.

Overview & Background

Buttons... indispensible for our daily lives. Even touch screens are spreading rapidly, it looks like they will be a part of our lives for a while. There is generally placed a push button for almost every electronic devices and they help us to control them easily. It is important for a student to know a tool's mode of operation best before use it. By completing this project, you will learn how this kind of push buttons work and will develop an understanding of the operating principles of them.

Objectives

students who participate in this project would be expect to learn,

  • how a button works.
  • how a simple interlocking system can be designed.
  • how to integrate 3D printed plastic with other types of materials (a spring made of aliminium).
  • what is the relationship between button's height and spring's total height.
  • which criterias must be considered to make button pushable.
  • the relationship between the button's push and release movements.
  • how to- design a product efficiently.
Audiences

10th grade students and above are appropriate for this project.

Subjects

Physics (springs), maths, geometry, technology and design, industrial product design.

Skills Learned (Standards)

By completing this project students will able to;

  • create a circular buttons.
  • align more than one shape to the center of each other
  • transform a cylinder into a tube
  • design a suitible hole to use ball-point pen spring inside the button
  • design seperate parts that can be intertwined easily
  • develop an understanding of how to produce a product more efficiently
  • develop an understanding of how to use a combination of different materials in one product
  • aware of how push buttons work
Lesson/Activity

To complete this project, first you can tell students to search abour push buttons. Even an example could bring to class and this would provide a fisrt hand information about how push buttons works.
Secondly, after a brief data gathering each student could generate an idea, that will help some people or solve any problem with push buttons.
Lastly, a deadline may be given them. And after printing, may ask stundets to test prototype in the problem context. So that, product's obstacles and incorrect parts could be detected by student and this will give him an idea of what will be fixed next.

Duration

It may take 2-3 class hours to complete project. In the first hour, let students generate their own ideas and this will led them to a unique or maybe an innovative push button design in tinkercad.

Prepraration

Tinkercad is free. You dont need any hard technologies at all. Before project, all students had been shown tinkercad basic commands and alignment functions.
And you need a simple ballpoint pen. For each project there must be one spring ready to use.

References

Before project, teacher or students may have review push button's functionality and mode of operation.

Rubric and assessment

Students should have designed a three pieces push button at the end of the project. Parts should be printed seperately. Printed parts must be good shaped and inner part should be move inside the outer part up and down frictionlessly. In order to combine with a typical spring, spring must be fit smoothly both upper and lower parts

nut M3 x4

description.text:
A bunch of tanks, stands, and a mechanical piece to make a little chemical processing site for 28mm wargaming terrain. The components are pretty plug and play, though the mixer/splitter is more or less designed to have 5 inputs and 1 output or vice versa. The file all.stil has all of the components for one of the 60mm tanks laid out so you can just hit "Multiply" in your print tool (e.g., Cura), and produce a bunch of them easily. In my actual construction, in the attached photo, I used a wooden dowel for the largest tank so I didn't have to wait for such a tall print (had to get this built for a deadline), but I've included a 120mm barrel to print that as well.

No supports are needed for this print, everything has been pieced out and has to be glued together instead. The end caps do have concave undersides, but the models include little popcorn supports, as pictured, that can be flicked off trivially with your fingernail.

I have a blog post here talking a bit about the design and construction of these models and the tank farm piece:

http://www.rocketshipgames.com/blogs/tjkopena/2016/05/medea-refinery-wip-part-5/

Printable X-Carve dust collector. See my instructable for more information:
http://www.instructables.com/id/X-Carve-CNC-Router-Dust-CollectorShoe/

Ancient "3d printing" Technique (Cylinder Seal VA-243)

This ancient analog Sumerian "3d printing" seal can be used to quickly print & share information into mud, wet sand and clay!

You can use the steps in this tutorial to make a seal with your own design for example logo/message/cartoon etc. or make a replica of one of the ancient Sumerian seals.
Don't forget to share it here on Thingiverse!

The steps in the tutorial can also be used for converting 2d pictures, illustrations, patterns, etc. into 3d printable bracelets, lithophanes and other round shaped things

The oldest found seals are around 3500 B.C. engraved with written characters or figurative scenes or both, used in the ancient times to roll an impression onto a surface, generally wet clay.

The seal I used in this tutorial is named: VA 243 (Its named that way because it is number 243 in the collection of the Vorderasiatische Museum in Berlin)

What can be learned from this model?:

  • Ancient visual way of teaching and storytelling
  • Ancient technology for quick spreading of information
  • How to use these seals
  • Simple way of analogue "3d printing/stamping"
  • Ancient 3d printing technique

What can be learned from this Tutorial?:

  • Tracing 2d image
  • Converting 2d into 3d object
  • Bending/rolling 3d models
  • variety of free (3d) software
  • Make your creations printable

Controversial knowledge:

  • The Sumerians had advanced astronomical knowledge of the planetary bodies in our solar system
  • The seal is showing Niburu / Planet X

Readers of Zecharia Sitchin’s books, particularly The 12th Planet, will recognize the above seal, VA 243. This seal is the centerpiece of Sitchin’s theory that the Sumerians had advanced astronomical knowledge of the planetary bodies in our solar system.

This knowledge was allegedly given to the Sumerians by extraterrestrials, whom Sitchin identifies as the Anunnaki gods of Sumero-Mesopotamian mythology. In the upper left-hand corner of the seal, Sitchin argues, one sees the sun surrounded by eleven globes. Since ancient peoples (including the Sumerians according to Sitchin) held the sun and moon to be “planets,” these eleven globes plus the sun add up to twelve planets. Of course, since we now know of nine planets plus our sun and moon, part of Sitchin’s argument is that the Sumerians knew of an extra planet beyond Pluto. This extra planet is considered by Sitchin to be Nibiru, an astronomical body mentioned in Mesopotamian texts. Sitchin’s works detail his contention that Nibiru passes through our solar system every 3600 years, and so some believers in Sitchin’s theory contend that Nibiru will return soon. Some followers of Sitchin’s ideas also refer to Nibiru as “Planet X”.
Is Sitchin correct – in whole or in part?

Continue reading why some say he is wrong:
http://www.sitchiniswrong.com/VA243seal.pdf

If we leave the right or wrong about the planets in the middle, this piece is still a fascinating piece of history and the print speed of this technique is amazing! ;)

Start printing like a ancient Sumerian today!

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Supports:

No

Tutorial

Design Steps:

  1. Find a picture of the Sumerian seal (or logo/message/cartoon etc.) you want to trace.
    • Use google image search and search for: "Sumerian Seal"
      (1.1 Optional: To make things more easy but less good final result, Click on "search tool" button and click color > "white" and find a nice line drawing of your subject of choice.)

  2. Import your picture and Digital trace the outlines of top view of your picture of the seal (or logo/message/cartoon etc.) using Adobe Illustrator and the pen tool.
    -Export as .SVG file.
    (GIMP +SVG plugin is a free alternative option)
    (Or if you choose option 1.1 in the first step you can skip the time consuming pen tracing and instead selected "Image trace" and play with the threshold slider to find the best result)

  3. Import the SVG into Sketchup close al faces and extrude faces
    Keep in mind:
    • The overhang/support material
    • 3d Printer capability's
    • Only the parts you want to press into the clay need to be extruded.
    • Export OBJ/STL

  4. Import in Blender and roll the model
    (Youtube Tutorial -> youtube.com/watch?v=b4ADqHZNKrQ )
    • Export OBJ/STL

  5. Import back into Sketchup and add a cylinder core
    -keep in mind the overhang/support material

  6. Import into Meshmixer and make it solid
    • Select your model and press the edit button > Make solid
      (Good alternative option https://makeprintable.com/ )

(Keep in mind, not all of the above steps are mentioned precisely, and you may need to fix some small issues on your own.)

Final result: Sumerian seal VA-243 Searching line drawings using Google image search and search tool option. Tracing the seal image using Illustrator and the pen tool. Close faces and extrude using Sketchup Press and roll the 3d printed cylinder seal into the clay After drying the clay (24hrs) After painting (paint used: Citadel Shade: Nuln Oil)

title: 5 Layer Pentahedron - triangular prism twisty puzzle

description.text:
This thing was inspired by MF8 Crazy Pentahedron series. I already did a 3 layer version and this is 5 layer pentahedron.

I am uploading 2 versions of parts. One is parts as is, without proper rotation, no supports. You can use your favorite techniques and tools to prepare parts for printing.

Most of the parts are bulging and can't be printed as is. I usually split such parts on 2 or 3 pieces that are easier for printing. Then these parts can be glued as into a single part using acethone (for ABS), or dichlorethan (for PLA). So other version of parts I am uploading is prepared in this way.

As my previous puzzle I printed this one as stickerless design. I split parts in the way so that I could print subparts with different color. Though you can still print it one color and apply vinyl stickers.

I am using 'front face' to refer to 3x5-pieces rectangular face, 'top face' for 6-piece triangle face. Number in the file name reflects how many times you should print the part. Please plan which part should be printed which color. Pieces have 'L' or 'R' suffix that mean left and right subparts, 'T' abd 'B' for top and bottom.

I am attaching Solidworks file so that you can see how I made it.

Unfortunately it moves not so smooth as it should be. Pieces are often catch each other on movements. Moreover corner pieces appear to be too loose. Yeah, this is design issue. I am open for suggestions how to fix that. Fortunately puzzle is still playable

Here is the video demonstrating turning quality https://youtu.be/ohK7KEzRvsE

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Graber i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm nozzle, 0.2mm layer

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I used ABS plastic for most of the parts, but PLA should work as well. However I strongly recommend printing core in PLA as it has much better layer adhesion (which is critical for core part)

Sand parts

Sand all corners and edges so that they are smooth. Inner parts should not have any roughness as it may catch other parts.

Glue split parts

Split parts should be glued. I would use acethone for ABS, or dichlorethan for PLA (remember, dichorethan is very toxic!!! use a good ventilation!)

Assembly

Center parts have a thin membrane at the hole - this makes printing easier. just drill the hole with 3mm drill.

Center pieces are screwed with M3 screws to core. Do not tighten it very much - parts should rotate freely. It is recommended to use special screws for twisty cubes - they have smooth part without a thread at screw head. This will allow smoother rotation and screw will not unscrew.

I recommend using springs. Without a spring puzzle will be too loose. Springs should be quite strong. I tried using springs from a pen - my puzzle tend to explode on every turn. Rubick's cube springs should work fine. You may look for springs and screws as spare parts for twisty puzzles (for example these http://www.championscubestore.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=75&products_id=612)

Center caps

Once puzzle is assembled it is time to attach caps. Caps are mounted using hooks. Just glue appropriate hooks into caps. Let glue to set before mounting cap on its place.

description.text:
Feet that replaces the original rubber once.
With these a larger and silent fan can be fitted over the stepper drivers to replace the noisy small 40x40 fan installed by Flashforge. The airflow for the PSU is also improved.

Please note that the SketchUp files is 10x scale.
This is a tip when drawing smaller things in SketchUp, make them 10x bigger and then use Meshlab to resize the stl files. SketchUp tends to get round of errors on small dimensions, and that leads to gaps and issues.

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

40%

Notes:

I printed these with Prima3D Value black PLA, 0.2mm with 40% infill.
Sliced with Simplify 3D.

The grey plastic of the Dreamer is a bit bent at the bottom, insert one end first and then twist the feet in. Makes for a snug fit. I put some small rubber feet on the bottom. 4 feet printed in one go. The layers are pretty awesome on the Dreamer.

title: Archimedes Spiral Bowl cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This simple design is based on the Archimedes Spiral and show how far you can bend wood ... even if you deal with plywood.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6 mm birch plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. The top panel had a beautiful dark inclusion, which would be traded as fault in many cases.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.
I used Illustrator and a script written by Sato Hiroyuki to create an approach of the Archimedes Spiral.

comments.text: Nice idea, but I don't have 1mm drill bit and even with 1mm it is impossible for me to cut this without altering the file because feet are too close to spiral. I don't mind using 2mm extra wood man :) If you could move them further apart, they would be much more useful for folks like me with 2mm drill bits ;)
comments.author: 3Dpassion

comments.text: This shouldn't be a problem if you are using a CAM-software. Entering the values of the tool diameter and defining the feet as part (cutting outside) you should be good. The tool-width-compensation will do the rest.
comments.author: 3Dpassion

comments.text: I am not very pro in CAM yet, but I use Fusion 360 software and It won't even let me import simple DXG. I had to model the 3D from this part and because sides were so close to the ring, I was not able to cut that with 2mm tool, so literally had to redraw the whole thing. Will try to cut it today for fun :) Will post photos if it works :)
comments.author: ZenziWerken

comments.text: Fusion360 is a great piece of software but it has a serious learning curve. You mightto take a look at Estlcam, which is fairly inexpensive and very easy to use. You can try it for free, but it will start nagging after a while.
comments.author: 3Dpassion

comments.text: I don’t find Fusion 360 any difficult. Learnibg curve - yes, but I’d rather learn more capable software. I am pretty fluent with cad design in general, just new to cnc and cam. There is probably a much simpler way to do it in F360, I just don’t know where that button is located lol
comments.author: ZenziWerken

description.text:
These bases were designed for standard 15mm scale infantry and cavalry models. Most 15mm scale metal models come with a pesky integrated base that can be difficult to remove. With these bases, just clip away enough of the integrated base to make it fit and glue the model into the recess. This will keep your model flush with the standard 2mm high basing and, with a little flock, you can hide the recess entirely.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! description.text:
Rubik´s Cube Assembled.

  • First Rubik´s Cube "3D Print and Play".
  • No screws, no mounting, no rework, orbital gears.
  • You do not need support material if you have a good printer,
    or you can use PVA as support material.

New version, now it is CUSTOMIZABLE!

The distance between pieces in the uploaded Cubes are:

  • 0.25 mm distance between the blocks;
  • 0.50 mm distance between the core;
  • You can alter the values in the Customizable section to prevent the pieces to fuse.

Instructions:

  • Use small extruder nouse <= 0.35;
  • Use small layer height <= 0.20;
  • Use the distance of pieces and core bigger than your printer layer height;
  • Use cooling all the time;
  • You need a good cooling system;
  • You need a precise printer;
  • It is not so easy, but can be done!

This object still in work process!

  • You will not be able to disassembly it!
  • This object is a remix of object:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:333889

You have 4 versions:

  • Normal - Just add the colors and play.

  • Dice notation - Just play! Like one braille, it can be used by visually impaired too. ;-D

  • No support pins, to print with PVA as support:
    Rubik_Cube_V2_Normal_Fixed.stl
    Rubik_Cube_V2_Dice_Fixed.stl

  • With support pins, to simple extruder printers:
    Rubik_Cube_V2_Normal_Sup_Fixed.stl
    Rubik_Cube_V2_Dice_Sup_Fixed.stl

Now with test pieces to test your printer,
with core distances from 0.25 mm to 0.75mm:

  • Test_Core.25mm.stl;
  • Test_Core.35mm.stl;
  • Test_Core.45mm.stl;
  • Test_Core.55mm.stl;
  • Test_Core.65mm.stl;
  • Test_Core.75mm.stl;
    Easy way to find the best "Core Distance" value for your printer.

The original idea is from thingiverse user William Johnson:

  • "I just think that the rubiks cube would make an excellent example for students of what 3D printers can really do in terms of creating preassembled objects with less pieces."
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/sirwejiv/about
    Thank you sirwejiv!

You can help me to do more things like this.

comments.text:
Ok. I always start with my cheapest filament for my first print just to uncover any potential issues. So I was able to do a complete print with HIPS. The outer squares seemed ok with only minimal cross overs except for the base. I need to use a raft to lift the base up away for more even print overall. But the center sphere seems to fuse more with the center square "anchors". I noticed that as the cube was being built the sphere would "wobble" when the extruder worked on it until the axis of the side center squares started being built. Maybe that wobble is contributing to the fusing? In short, using HIPS I couldn't get a cube with any moving part. Do you recommend another filament for "dimensional accuracy" for more precision printing?
That problem seems like something PVA would prevent. In order to use a secondary extruder for PVA I will need another object at the exact same coordinates that is only all the "gaps". I use Cura and it does an extrusion merge with the two objects.
I am using the new TAZ 6 from lulzbot.

comments.author: jsirgado

comments.text:
Hi sirwejiv!
This weekend I made some tests.
I printed a small cube(70%) with a ratio of 1 to 2 between layer size and distance between parts.
All parts are good but the core melted.
Then I created an object with 2 pieces with the same size to simulate the core "ball-joint",
after some tests I found 0.75mm distance between the pieces and 0.25 layer height.
With this ratio, all parts are good and the object works great!
I believe that the 1 to 3 between layer size and parts distance
is a good ratio, and I used cooling all time in 100%.
I do not printed the full size cube yet because it will take more than 20 hours!
I will return you when done!

Ready for a in depth project?
The engine runs at a high rate of speed, but gets to hot for PLA after 2-5 min. Id like to see someone make this made in ABS or a better power/solenoid setup for better heat tolerances.
to make this engine you must know how to use and program an Arduino. u must know the basics of electronics. Videos
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SMtnZdwXaJs http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kVJHjs5Qt-M

If you cannot find the supplies I used or just want to change something I included Google sketch up files included for your modifications.
printing the ARM, ELBO, AND BACEPLATE are not necessary, I just use it as a desk fan. The overview
The sensor shines LED's on the sensor disk and picks up the reflected light. The sensor disk is half Dark and half light (I used tape and white PLA) As the engine and the disk spins the photo sensor acts as a position sensor. The Arduino uses this date to tell what Solenoid pistons to fire. the Arduino cannot handle the current needed to turn over the engine so I used 2 TIP120 transistors on a 6V power supply 2 AMP. You will need (all from RadioShack)
-enamel coated wire
-Arduino and power supply
-2 TIP120 transistors (and necessary circuit supplies)
-alternate power supply for solenoids(I used 6V 2 AMP)
-2 LED's
  • photo resistor
  • nails cut to length that fit into piston File
  • switches
    good luck!

its harder the more positions you have due to the fact that your using light as the position sensor. its easy to use photo sensors to tell light and dark 0 and 180. once you start adding in other positions you need to add parts to the reflective dick that don't reflect as much. after you do that you will have to worry about the ambient light in the room throwing off your position sensors readings.
I used light as a position sensor because its a frictionless sensor no rubbing contacts that can burn out etc. I will have to think of a better position sensor for the V8 model I'm working on. suggestions?

comments.text: You could put holes in the disk and have four LEDs on one side and four photodetectors on the other side. Light can only transmit through the disk when the holes line up with an LED/photodetector pair. I used this trick when I made this motor: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11164http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
comments.author: 7thCrook

comments.text: that's an awesome engine you made! I couldn't use LED's like that because the power stroke needs to hold for the entire 180. if the LED only passes one hole then the piston will only fire for a microsecond as the hole passed. I could cut 180 strips around the disk but then I would need to make a strip for every different degree that needed different timing. I could go classic and use cams and switches etc. but I'm going for frictionless position sensor.
comments.author: mattmoses

comments.text: You could 3D print a piece with curved slots to allow the light to transmit over a larger range of angles. I made a customizable example in OpenSCAD available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:161194http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...

author: shivinteger

description.text:
This part simply holds your phone for a "desktop" mode.  This will probably work for many other phones, but i have only tested with the Nexus One.
Im sure you can cut a hole in the bottom and slip a power cord in, but it wont be as simple as dropping a phone in and lifting it out.
Approximate build time: 3 hours +/- 0.5 hour
GCode has been provided as a reference, but is probably not compatible with your particular printer.
Simply print and set your phone it.

author: uck

description.text:
I love Snarkwise's Zencubes, however because of the amount of metal on the UP! printer - it caused the majority of the magnets to jump out, no matter what I did to prevent it.
So this is the fix! A mash-up to make the Zencube take Zenpins! A BIG thankyou to Snarkwise for posting the scad files which really helped my learning curve of openscad in this process!
I'll upload the scad file once I've cleaned up my code. These also have a flat bottom (no cross for removing a pin). Please note - as much as I have tested these and the pins stay put quite well - if these are going to be for toys - adult supervision and only for kids old enough to know NOT to put things in their mouths! This design includes small parts that could be harmful.

I have included two different clearances - and the test-blocks to save time.
These are so you can find the most snug fit of the pins.
On the UP! I prefer the 0.2mm clearance. The easiest way to get the pins in - once magnet is in the pin, put the pin on the diagonal with the opening for the magnet lightly wedged into the edge of the hole (see pics) and then push the other side in.
With 0.2mm clearance and this technique, the pins are a really snug fit and the only way to get them back out is with a flat-head jewellers screwdriver.

comments.text: Good to know, I'll change default holeTolerance to 0.2. I want these pins to be perfect.

title: Rod to Rod dial indicator bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this dial indicator bracket to allow for aligning X carriage rods to the Y rods. Most similar bracket designs place the dial mount between the rod clips, which only allows the tool tip to reach the bed. However, X axis rods should be Y axis rods to ensure the carriage travel is aligned to the Y rods. The bed has its own positioning mechanism (leveling screws) which should be removed from the rod (axis) squaring process.

To get the probe to sit correctly on the Y rods, remove the ball end.

Required hardware (per bracket):

  • (1) m5x20 hex cap bolt
  • (1) m5 locknut

For best results, adjust your bed to it's lowest position and home your printer on Z to allow the probes to reach the Y rods. If you can't move your print bed out of the way, mount the brackets facing backwards. Turn on the indicator before mounting and be careful not to zero it out. Make sure the bracket is seated all the way down on the rods and that the (sans-ball) probe is on top of the Y rod.

Why do I have two indicators? Because the X rods pivot at points outside the carriage travel range; adjusting one Z rod will change the height all the way across to the opposite mount point of the X rods. Having two indicators in place allows both sides to be adjusted simultaneously for faster, more accurate results.

Printer:

Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15%

Make sure to get all the support out of the adapter slot. The slot has a small amount of play, but the part will tolerate being tightened down if the top/bottom are thick enough (I used 1.2mm)

The hex nut capture includes a support plug which needs to be broken out (compare thing view to the picture).

This bracket is designed to work with the indicators shown and may not fit other models.

title: Recessed Monster Bases (15mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These bases were designed for standard 15mm scale monster models. Most 15mm scale metal models come with a pesky integrated base that can be difficult to remove. With these bases, just clip away enough of the integrated base to make it fit and glue the model into the recess. This will keep your model flush with the standard 2mm high basing and, with a little flock, you can hide the recess entirely. I've included some rocky rubble bits which help to flavor the base and blend in with what's left of the integrated basing.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

(Models shown are 15mm Hundred Years War soldiers from Corvus Belli and various monsters from Reaper's Bones line.)

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I created these tray organizers for the board game Orleans by Reiner Stockhausen. They sit 40mm tall which, in my printing of the box from Tasty Minstrel Games, leaves just enough space above or below for all of the boards and instructions and the lid closes completely.

I do not have any of the extra Kickstarter or expansion pieces so if you do, these will probably not hold everything.

When I began this project, my assumption was that the bags would be the easiest to find space for because they were amorphous and would fit wherever I squeezed them. The reality was that they took up the most space because they do not compress and therefore have a minimum volume. In the end, they fit down the middle between two rows of the trays.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

ORION Delta 3D Printer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.35

Infill:

30%

I used Inkscape to lay out the overview in the box, and then Sketchup Make to design the individual trays. My printer has a smallish print volume so I had to keep the size of each individual piece down. I have included the Sketchup files for remixing.

When building my C-Bot printer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:500041), I had a hard time getting the wheels tight against the rail. To do it properly, you need 3 hands. Sadly, I was born with only two. So I came up with this idea of using a clamp to hold the wheels tight on the rail. This unit provides a flat spot for the clamp to apply the pressure instead of putting the clamps directly on the wheels. It is designed to fit around the wheel, not touching it, and apply the pressure on the spacers around the axle the wheel is on.

I am including the OpenSCAD file if changes need to be made for a particular setup.

WARNING! DO NOT OVER TIGHTEN THE CLAMP! Applying too much pressure can deform the wheel, bend the axle, or even force the wheel into the slot in the rail. Please don't ask me how I know this will happen.

title: Rostock Max Duet Calibration 13 Probe Points Test

description.text:
This STL is designed to print a .3mm high disc at each of the 13 probe points of MHackney's Rostock Max bed.g script (pasted below with my own H values for deflection). You can print the pieces and measure their thickness with calipers or a micrometer to test your own accuracy.

Here is a description of how to use the H values for hotend deflection. http://reprap.org/wiki/Configuring_and_calibrating_a_delta_printer_using_the_dc42_fork_of_RepRapFirmware#Probing_by_pushing_the_bed_with_the_hotend

I've also attached a .txt file with GCode that you can use to position the head at Z5 above each probe point. Run the autocalibration first, then use the GCode to visit each probe point and manually jog down the Z height until you get a good smooth feeling drag on a piece of paper. Document that Z position for all 13 points, and incorporate them into the probing script to account for the deflection of your hotend at each point.

; Probe the bed and do 6- or 7-factor auto calibration

G30 P0 X-108.25 Y-62.50 H-0.25 Z-99999 ; X tower
G30 P1 X0.00 Y-125.00 H-0.1 Z-99999 ; between X-Y towers
G30 P2 X108.25 Y-62.50 H-0.07 Z-99999 ; Y tower
G30 P3 X108.25 Y62.50 H-0.03 Z-99999 ; between Y-Z towers
G30 P4 X0.00 Y125.00 H-0.25 Z-99999 ; Z tower
G30 P5 X-108.25 Y62.50 H-0.36 Z-99999 ; between Z-X towers
G30 P6 X-54.13 Y-31.25 H0.1 Z-99999 ; X tower
G30 P7 X0.00 Y-62.50 H0 Z-99999 ; between X-Y towers
G30 P8 X54.13 Y-31.25 H0 Z-99999 ; Y tower
G30 P9 X54.13 Y31.25 H-0.01 Z-99999 ; between Y-Z towers
G30 P10 X0.00 Y62.50 H0.2 Z-99999 ; Z tower
G30 P11 X-54.13 Y31.25 H-0.11 Z-99999 ; between Z-X towers
G30 P12 X0 Y0 Z-99999 S6 ; center and auto-calibrate 6 factors

I've also attached the RSDOC source file so that you can edit it as needed in DesignSpark.

description.text:
This design is an easy to print mockup of the (4th) Doctor Who Sonic Screwdriver. It's not an exact duplicate, but close and modified to make it easy print and place a Arduino Pro Mini inside. It will provide a good platform to write interesting code for the Arduino.

The circuit diagram includes a push button switch, tilt switch, 16 position rotary switch, LED, temperature sensor, and piezo speaker.

Printer:

FolgerTech 2020 Prusa i3 AL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The threads on the screw cap (Tube4) and base (Tube1) are pretty small. This may cause your biggest problems printing.

The original 4th Doctor Sonic is silver.

Assembly of the Shell

For wiring, I recommend wire wrap or 24 gauge solid core wire.

  1. Drill out Tube3 piece with 1/4" bit both from the bottom and the front (so that an LED can be mounted).
  2. Solder two thin wires (about 8") to an LED and thread through Tube3 and Tube2 (don't forget to mark the anode wire).
  3. The LED, Tube3 and Tube2 can now be glued together.
  4. Insert the piezo speaker into Tube2 and solder two wires (about 8").
  5. Create the daughter board as shown in the 4thsonic.jpg.
  6. Solder two wires to the push button switch.
  7. Drill two holes on Tube1 about an inch down from the top where the push button switch will be mounted and the rotary switch can be accessed.
  8. Use epoxy putty to mount the push button switch.
  9. Thread all the wires through Tube1 and glue Tube1 to Tube2.
  10. Attach the Arduino Pro Mini as shown in 4thsonic.jpg.
  11. Attach the FTDI board to the sonic and program.
  12. Stuff all the wires and then the Arduino into the base and connect the battery.

Parts List:

Sparkfun Arduino Pro Mini 328, 5v/16mhz
1 LED (any color)
220 Ohm 8 pin Single-In-Line (SIL) resistor network
Piezo Buzzer - PS1240 (.47” diameter)
LM35 Temperature Sensor
Mini Rotary Switch (such as Raraohm SDR-16CT)
Pushbutton switch (use a switch with a tall button and small base, space is tight).
SW-520D Lacoste Ball Switch
FTDI Adapter USB Controller
Tiny Circuits Tinyduino 3.7v Battery

description.text: Power pod for use with the Flite Test mighty minis. This design doesn't included any thrust angle, this didn't prove to be a problem though on my FT Tiny Trainer, I just had to do a little rudder trimming to make it track straight. I found that the original design that uses BBQ skewers liked to rip the holes wider after a few crashes causing the power pod to become loose. To solve this I decided to use popsicle sticks instead of skewers on the power pod. Depending on your printer' you may have to sand your popsicle sticks down because it was designed for a snug fit.

description.text: HMS Nelson (pennant number 28) was one of two Nelson-class battleships built for the Royal Navy between the two World Wars. She was named in honour of Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson the victor at the Battle of Trafalgar. The Nelsons were unique in British battleship construction, being the only ships to carry a main armament of 16-inch (406 mm) guns, and the only ones to carry all the main armament forward of the superstructure. These were a result of the limitations of the Washington Naval Treaty. Commissioned in 1927, Nelson served extensively in the Atlantic, Mediterranean, and Indian oceans during World War II. She was decommissioned soon after the end of the war and scrapped in 1949. (wikipedia)

description.text: This is a component of the Free Universal Construction Kit, a collection of adapter bricks that enable complete interoperability between a wide range of popular childrenâ€™s construction toys. By allowing any piece to join to any other, the Kit encourages totally new forms of play across otherwise closed systems. As with other grassroots interoperability remedies, the Free Universal Construction Kit implements proprietary protocols in order to provide a public service unmet, or unmeetable, by corporate interests. description.text:
This is a simple mount to adapt the titan bracket to my very heavily hacked up mendel max 2.

I have taken a piece of 20x60 vslot which is my x carriage / extruder setup.

Print one set, use M4 screws to secure the titan extruder. I'm using a 34mm deep which I picked up from lulzbot.

Mounting hardware:

4-6 M5 10mm low profile
4-6 tnuts
4-6 M5 washers

If you use normal profile M5 screws you likely won't be able to get the bottom one in without drilling/carving.

Feel free to hack on the scad. Either post comments with changes / suggestions or post as a remix. I did make a slight change from my original design - I had the m4 titan mount centered. This caused issues with the cooling fins pushing up against the corner so I chose to offset the m4 slots.

I've printed with this mount a few times I no longer consider it a work in progress - works fine for me so far.

RepRap

Printer:

mendel max 2 - hacked to hell

Doesn't Matter

comments.text:
I consider buying a 3d printer (perhaps a Dremel Idea Builder) for printing dungeon tiles and accessories.
I soaked up almost every information on printing these or similar tiles, but i hardly ever could find info on the printing time.
For example, how long does it take to print just one corner piece?
I know it depends on the printer and the setup, but could you please post your experience?
comments.author: L-Chris

comments.text: Thanks for the questions.  I just ran a couple previews of a singe corner tile.   I typically run my printer at a resolution of .1mm and  a speed of 80mm/sec.   At these settings, a single corner tile takes about 1h 37min to print and costs about 42 cents (based on a $23 kg of plastic).   However, if I changed the resolution to .2mm and cranked my printer speed to 150mm/sec, It would only take 36min to print.  I run my printer throughout the day when I can and load six tiles on the build plate at night.  My collection of tiles grew quite quickly.

description.text:
UPDATE: 8/9/16 Uploaded Fusion360 file for anyone who may want to edit and change. If you do add/change anything please share!

Thanks!

UPDATE: Both parts, the gantry and fan duct have been updated and replaced. I have printed and installed and working great! Really happy with how they finally turned out.

I printed the gantry with Blue Hatchbox PLA at .24 layer height at 200*C with 50% infill at 60mm/s. There will be a slight amount of cleanup needed after you print due to all the overhangs. Make sure to clean up well where the stepper motor slides in as the bridging may have sagged a little and it is a tight fit.

Cheers~
Rock

Here is a new E3D Titan Extruder compatible gantry for the Eclips3D printer. Please note, I have not installed and tested this yet. Right after I got it printed my wife confiscated my 3D printer room and we turned it into her new sewing room. The Eclips3D has now been relocated to the garage :( Let me know if you have any troubles. I will update as soon as I can install and test it out.

comments.text: I am up and running with this and just did first test print - beautiful! I'll post pictures when I have a chance. The holes for the bushings were way too tight on the first attempt, so I opened them up to a diameter of 12.4mm in Blender and reprinted it. They were still a little tight, and I eased them off by wrapping some sandpaper round the end of a 10mm rod and opening them up slightly. After that the bushings fitted easily and the movement on the rods was very smooth. I am using the V2 fan duct for now.
comments.author: animoose

comments.text: I printed this at the weekend, and one thing I found is that with the new E3D heat block + silicone cover combination, the fan duct just touches the cover. From my experience this means it will soften and deform over time. Any chance you could make a variant which has the part closest to the block moved back by a couple of millimeters? (Or make the F360 file for it available, though as I don't really know what I'm doing with F360, this might work out less well.)

comments.text: Any comments on how well the design works now that you've had a chance to use it for a while? I am thinking of getting a Titan and so I'm interested to know how it's gone.
comments.author: animoose

comments.text:
Yes, I am now able to print with flexible filament which never worked before the Titan.
I am printing with this stuff right now: https://www.botfeeder.ca/filastic-flexible-filament/
The upgrade to the Titan is definitely worthwhile for printing flexible filament.
comments.author: animoose

comments.text: So far it has been great. A couple things I really like. There is less wheight traveling around up there. The tension adjustment seems to be a nice touch. Out of the box it works really well with flexible filament. Just printed up some test pieces with Ninjaflex and they came out great. The filament guidpath is perfect and the flexible filament does not bind up and escape the extruder. I was able to get Andrews extruder to work with it with some simple mods but occasionally I would get some runaway filament. You also have the option to set it up with 3mm filament if you wanted. And it just looks cool lol. That's all I can think of for now. If you are considering to get one. You won't be disappointed. The prints are coming out great!
comments.author: animoose

comments.text: Did you try the pancake motor? It removed even more weight from the gantry. You just need to change the extruder_steps_per_mm to 425 (from 155). I tried it and it works fine. Note: I did need to put a spacer (cork motor spacer) between the motor and the gantry since the motor is so narrow the screws for the titan were a bit long.
comments.author: Rock75

comments.text: I did. I just uploaded a new photo showing the gantry installed with the new stepper. I did not have it installed at first because the new stepper was not working. Found out that StepperOnline shipped it with the wrong cable configuration. Once I rewired the cable to the appropriate connections it worked great. I had purchased two of the smaller pancake steppers and decided on using the slightly larger one as it had the correct just connector preinstalled on the stepper itself. The smaller one just had bare wires that needs a connector added to it (at the time I did not have the necessary duppont connector to add to it. I am really happy with the reduced weight! As the Eclips3D is already a little top heavy any weight we can save up there helps a lot with the stability.
comments.author: jjlink

comments.text: I just Dremel-ed out the rod holes a bit; now it moves like butter as well. :)

description.text:
IMPORTANT NOTE: Since people keep getting this wrong. In order to print these out, you have to leave it in the "all" view mode. If you create the thing while it's in "assembled" it will not be remixed properly, the transparent parts will not render and you will have parts missing in your remix. The "assembled" view mode is just for you to be able to visualize your creations.

Fully parametric OpenSCAD with in browser Customizer support, this item will allow you to design and generate your own centrifuges for your range of needs. These can be used to pump fluids by sucking through the top inlet and blowing out the side outlets. With controls for the impeller, housing, caps, inlet and outlet options, this item is aimed to fit all of your small scale hobby needs.

I personally use this for extracting vapor from vaporizers and E-cigs for creating my own miniature fog machines.

This is currently a work in progress and I hope to get some videos up soon.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The view setting "all" will place all parts on the same plane allowing you to export all the parts together in a single STL file, for better ease of use.

You cannot download the STLs if you are in "assembled" view mode, you must change it to either "all" or just about anything besides the "assembled" view mode. "Assembled" is just the mode that helps you to see how your piece looks when put together.

title: Kingdom Death: Monster - Slimline Gear Grid for Small Build Plates

description.text:
This is a "gear grid" for the hobby game Monster (by Kingdom Death).

This grid holds nine "gear" cards in its four cells and sits on a table in front of a player. The game ships with a flat, card stock gear grid on top of which cards are placed: the flat card stock allows cards to shift during play.

The idea behind this design is to solve that problem with a slimline 3D grid that can be built on machines with smaller build plates.

On my Flashforge Creator Pro, I can build one of these in about an hour and 15 minutes.

(If I build without a base, I can shave about 20 minutes off of that, but the hit I take on general stability and "neatness" is pretty severe, given the overall tininess of the design.)

As far as assembly goes, there is some post-build assembly required.

The grid is printed in three pieces: two "stem" pieces and a trunk. Each "stem" is connected to the "trunk" at the triangular junction pieces.

I used some cheap ABS filament to print, and 3M Scotch Super Glue Gel, which works just fine.

Complete design and iteration notes can be found on my Kingdom Death blog.

I was inspired to make this thing by Fddlstyx's gear grid, though I did not start my design with any components of that thing.

I went through three major design variations before settling on my final design. Some images of the design process, which mostly took place using colored pencils and Tinkercad, follow.

A build of versions 3b and 3d (left and right, respectively), showing the inversion of structural supports and the addition of more Version 3c, the version that ended up being too wide for my build plate, as a sketch and Tinkercad work-up.

The bookshelf you see required almost 2 spools (1 kilogram each) of PLA Filament and about 70 hours worth of printing. It is a big print, project ended up being more work than i had planned (especially when i found out that all lumber sold is undersized by about .250 in. and i had to redesign it all) but i'm very happy with the shelf. The shelf you see is about 5 ft. X 2.75 ft X 1 ft. and required a little over 100 screws.

This is a 60.86 mm diameter by 352.49 mm high model of the M38A2 100 pound inert practice bomb. This was filled with sand and sometimes a small marker explosive then used during target practice in the forties and fifties. The originals were 48 inches long with a 9 inch diameter. The sheet metal is slightly off scale to make the fins 2 mm thick so it is easy to print on an FDM machine. If you scale this so it's 304 mm high ( .862 of it's height ) it would be quarter scale. One of the assembly pegs is under the tail assembly and doubles as a support during printing. Glue together, add eyelets and finish as desired. Should print pretty well without supports but you might wanna turn them on anyway for the underside of the fins and between the peg and tail assembly.

The nose cone goes on top of the body peg. That will make the places for the hangers end up in the right place. The peg that prints under the fins is used to fix the tail to the body. Don't bother downloading the "bombs away" STL, I just wanted to see how they would look in formation in thingview.
Made in SketchUp.

This is the rocket that I used in my "Make your own Rocket Cannon" video. To see this rocket in action click the link below!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7XIJSvsCpHQ

I used 16% fill when I printed this and it holds up nice and strong after every shot. But feel free to customize this and use your own print settings! This was my first time using Sketchup so the rocket may not look the nicest. I printed this in a MakerBot Replicator 2.

title: Wanhao i3 Maker Select Filament Guide and Riser v4

description.text:
Updated the design by making a interlocking ring thing. I was inspired by thing 1348253 and thought that might resolve my BINDING issue as you reach the top of the z axis. cheaper filament that is brittle sometimes breaks at this point. SO I copied the idea but I only need 2 rings. the filament runs through the "ball" in the middle.

I uploaded 3 additional versions. one is with no ball bearing at all just a larger opening. the other 2 are the ball bearing with a 4mm and 5mm hole to accept a PTFE tube.

I also brought the arm closer in to the center of the printer. there really is no reason to have the arm so far out since the head does not move on Y the BED moves on why. this will reduce the axis bend further though only on Y the head moves on X so that bend will remain. I am hoping the swively thingy will help with this.

I have a big print in progress so I have not printed this yet but see no reason it would be a problem. I will print one tomorrow.

of course this is also a riser lifting the filament holder UP a bit so the larger spools will fit.

Finally got a clean print (bad extruder stepper) and WOW does it work so much better now. the ball pivot really works too.

I am going to make a v5 with a larger hole in the ball pivot to accept a PTFE tube! and I think that mod will about do it for this part!

I am thinking about putting 5 holes in the arm to hold my allen keys but I am not sure if I want to mar its clean lines doing that.

looks like you need an M5 10mm as the existing bolt is too short. I had an assortment pack lying around so I just grabbed one.

Now your external walled rooms and corridors can have arrow slits as well. All those poor buildings that had no defenses can be upgraded to give defenders an shot at invaders. Imagine how many of your minis will now be saved from roving bands of monsters.

description.text:
I wanted to mount a flag to my car for memorial day. Realized. I have a damned 3D printer. No duct tape and rope. lets MAKE something professional and permanent (reusable)

SO I made this. it slips over my 1 7/8ths inch ball. I believe it will also have enough play to fit a 2" ball though I can not test just yet (I will update when I do)

the flag pole goes in the smaller hole. you need to drill a 1/4" hole through your flag pole a 1/4" bolt goes through and secures the flag pole.

2 1/4" bolts go through the other two holes AFTER you slip it over the ball and they secure it snugly into place so it can not fall off.

the plastic alone is probably not strong enough. good strong gust or just go fast enough and even as thick as this it I am betting it would break.

now get one of those thick rubber bungie hook hold downs like this

http://www.amazon.com/TEKTON-6190-10-Inch-EPDM-Rubber/dp/B003DN3RC4

place that in your open hatch or trunk lid so it will NOT reach your flag pole without stretching a bit. close the hatch or trunk on the strap make sure its firm. now stretch and snap around your flag pole.

your done. the bungie will take the hits and force and keep those forces from translating into leverage force into your printed mount.

the mount now just has to hold the flag bottom in place and keep it from moving around which it did splendidly today all day while I was delivering pizza. Nice.

Just make sure you flag does not touch the ground when at rest. You will probably want most of the flag under the roof line to keep it from being ripped off especially if your going to go fast. I don't suggest for highway travel. even if the flag holds it might whip around and mar up your cars paint. I was fine up to 40mph I did not try faster and had no need to while delivering.

I will add more in place and ready to go pictures and video tomorrow when light is better (Dark by the time I got home tonight at 2200)

The part has a socket for the hex heads of the 1/4" bolts on the side I used a washer a lock washer and a wing nut so no tools are needed.

if you need to remove just spin off the flag shaft nut pop out the bolt and remove the flag. you can leave the mount in place for later or when more convenient to remove and it will remove the same way. spin off the wing nuts and remove.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qyomRiBppDI

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select i3v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

High infill for strength and large layer height for speed. I printed this in roughly 8 or 9 hours. so overnight.

the wedges under the bolt holes are not for strength but so you can print with zero support at all. Drop on bed and go.

would look a lot nicer at .2mm but your never going to look at this up close really and it looks absolutely fine from a couple feet away or even holding it in your hands.

Preseat the bolts. slide the in put a washer on and spin the wing nuts on and tighten till the bolts fully seat in their formed cavities. pop them back out and put it into operation. Otherwise no post print work needed.

description.text:
I've really put to use my new timber rendering skills in the new Tudor Wall set. Having looked at hundreds of photos of tudor walls, I realized that there are hundreds of variations on the wood layouts. This set of walls is the most basic of the styles. I'll be releasing at least two sets of wall variations so you can build many different building looks all with the same basic set.

Set 1: A variety of diagonal wood pieces
Set 2: Cross beams and cross beams with each of the diagonals from set 1

I've done my best to make for both good wood grain, as well as a stucco texture.

description.text:
This is a prototype bolt and magazine well lock-out for a Just Right Carbine. The insert is based of a 9 mm Glock magazine, as such no other calibers have been tested. This BOLT MAG LOCKOUT (version JRC9-BML1E) is also designed to accept a standard pistol cable lock for added "lockout" potential.

Instructional video can be viewed on SBS Extensions YouTube Channel (click link for video).

UPDATE: (2016-06-11) Replaced original (~3 MB) STL file with a smaller sized one (1.63 MB), for faster downloads.

Notes:

SUGGESTED ITEM PRINT SETTINGS

  • 30% to 100% Infill
  • 3 Shells minimum
  • No Supports required
  • No Raft required or recommended
  • Hot End: 240C [based on 2 rolls of Taulman 3D n-vent (Amphora AM 1800)]
  • Hot Bed: 60C [based on 2 rolls of Taulman 3D n-vent (Amphora AM 1800)]
  • Filament diameter: 1.74 mm [based on 2 rolls of Taulman 3D n-vent (Amphora AM 1800)]

PLEASE NOTE:

  1. STL file was saved in its suggested printing orientation, rotate around Z-axis as required.
  2. Part has been designed using Taulman 3D N-Vent (Amphora AM 1800) filament.
  3. Print Speed, Temperatures settings for N-Vent were based of Original Prusa i3 MK2 Slic3r settings for ColorFabb XT (Amphora AM 1800) and translated to MakerBot.
  4. Do not use an enclosure, when using N-Vent to print item.
  5. Active cooling required, when using N-Vent to print item.
  6. PLA filament not recommended for final use; only use impact resistant filament types: ABS, PETG, etc.
  7. Scale up STL model by ~2% (i.e. 102.3%) when 3D printing in ABS, to compensate for shrinkage.

description.text:
This is a total remake of a popular car Remote Transmitter Cover. I eventually had enough problems with mine, I just created a better unit to house the PCB & battery. If you model is different in size. There is sufficient documentation and logic to modify to your needed unit size.

*Brand Names (also-known-as, or resemble): Hornet, Valet, Automate, Equalizer, Pro Guard, Python Sidewinder, Wasp, Viper, etc...

*Parts:
There are 5 parts: Bottom case, Top cover, button plate, and two internal button plugs.

*Part to retain from old unit:

  1. Screw
  2. Original split ring with chain.

*What you will need to complete this project:

  1. A new slightly larger Split Ring.
    In increasing the size of the key-chain holder, to make the unit stronger. The original metal ring became just to small.

  2. Glue (for your type of Plastic)
    Though the internal buttons are designed to be snapped on to the button structure plate, gluing them affixes them into place permanently.

*What if:

  1. The cover is designed to be a 'perfect fix'. Though you may think it does not fit the first time, it has been designed to be very snug.

Wanhao Duplicator i3 / Cocoon Create

Yes

0.1

Solid Fill

Fill Density: 25% or higher %

OpenSCAD

Started with new buttons, then continued on to create a whole new unit. A simple cover and button replacement would not fit correctly, so designed a new unit from the ground up.

Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner  
This shows the before and after results of scanning a kind of shiny object and then scanning it again after spraying it with a can of dry shampoo power I got at the grocery store.  The shampoo powder rubs right off cleanly afterwards.  
The fumes from the dry shampoo is pretty bad though, so use it in a well ventilated area. (I don't know how people use this stuff on their hair, phew... maybe I just got some that was particularly fragrant?)

This is a higher version of Dasakis' enclosure!

I need more place in the box for easier cabling, higher heatsinks or longer pins at the stepper drivers (for easier cooling).

The enclosure you see at the photos hasn't been used, because I bought a RADDS 1.5.
So it contains none of the two 50mm fans and nealy all the support!

author: eraviaam

title: Basic GoPro Handle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this GoPro handle for filming at the Maker Faire. This is the "basic" version of the handle but works quite nicely! The handles are held to the body with 1" long 1/4-20 screws and 1/4-20 nuts epoxied into the handles. Image shown has first gen base FYI.

You will need to print 1 top handle, one handle basic 1 and one handle basic 2. Also you will need 2 handles no o rings. These have the hex molded in for the 1/4-20 nuts that get epoxied in place. I tried to design enough tolerance gap but you may need to re-enlarge the holes with sandpaper or a 1/4" drill bit.

How to assemble

I put together a quick video explaining how to put the GoPro handle together. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Udwq238Kbhs

comments.text: For those complaining that the uploader didn't create the models, there is a thing in copyright law called "derivative works."  So if you take an image, and then put your own work into modifying or transforming it, then you have some ownership rights of the end product.  It's not really a clean definition (much like "fair use") which is one reason copyright lawsuits get so messy.  IMHO, based on what he says about what he did to the original files, I think he's got more to worry about from the trademark of the names and symbols than ownership of the model files.

I have printed the Hex Tie by cahorton, and I have found for me this problem: Visible side is the printbed side of the tiles. At my printer (multiple use of the same capton tape) it is not equal one to annother. So I have made a redesign. Now the top layer is visible side. Also, it is easier to assemble with the connectors.
At assembly, check if the printhead moving direction is the same for all tiles. Turn the hex tiles to same direction.
Mid pieces are assembled with a screw.
Lock (behind neck) I have made:
normal pieces, drilled in the mid, glued super magnet to each.
Pieces 05tie.stl, 10tie.stl, 15tie.stl are with angle 05deg, 10deg, 15deg. I have used 15degree pieces only.

comments.text: I like the idea that the top side is the visible side and the magnet lock is just ingenious, but the colors are horrible! a blue with yellow tie? And the shape is also not very tie-like...
